column1: #Text=Travel ban 2.0 exempts Iraqis , U.S. permanent residents

#Text=On Monday , U.S. president Donald Trump signed in the Oval Office a revised version of his executive order barring entry to the United States by refugees and individuals from certain Muslim-majority countries .

#Text=While the previous ban , which caused chaos at airports and drew considerable criticism from within and outside of the U.S. government , covered seven countries , this one names only six and specifically exempts legal permanent residents and anyone who already has a visa to enter the country , or a visa revoked by the earlier executive order .
#Text=Residents of Syria , Iran , Libya , Somalia , Sudan and Yemen must now wait 90 days for visas .
#Text=Iraq was removed following concerns that people who had helped the United States military and Iraqi government during and after the Iraq War might be left in danger .
#Text=Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said this was because the U.S. State Department and Iraqi government improved the vetting process , though he did not say what exactly changed .
#Text=Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi spoke with President Trump by phone and Vice President Pence in person .
#Text=A senior official with the Trump administration also told reporters the Iraqi government had promised " timely repatriation " for Iraqi nationals whom the U.S. has decided to deport .
#Text=There is still a 120-day moratorium on accepting refugees into the U.S. , though the ban on Syrian refugees is no longer indefinite .
#Text=The new order omits language that gave priority to religious minorities , which critics such as National Public Radio 's Domenico Montanaro read as " Christians .
